importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article, which covers Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season, highlights the ongoing narrative of dramatic comebacks and quarterback performance changes in the league.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the start of the 2025 NFL season to Week 7 reflects a trend of late-game comebacks and quarterback instability, indicating a season marked by unpredictability and high volatility.

keyTakeAways: The 2025 NFL season has seen an unprecedented number of lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation, with 26 such occurrences through Week 7—more than in any previous season.

Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter against the New York Giants, becoming the first team since 2007 to overcome a 161-0 lead when leading by 18 or more after three quarters.

Second-year quarterback Bo Nix of the Denver Broncos delivered a career-defining performance, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, and eventually sealing the win with a game-winning field goal as time expired.

Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage (88.5%) with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to achieve 90% completion, over 200 yards passing, and over 50 yards rushing in a single game.
Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa was benched in the fourth quarter after throwing three interceptions, including one returned for a touchdown, in a 31-6 loss to the Cleveland Browns.
New York Jets quarterback Justin Fields was benched at halftime after a poor first half (6-of-12, 46 yards), replaced by Tyrod Taylor, who threw two interceptions in his start.
The article emphasizes the volatility of the NFL season, showcasing dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and high-profile quarterback benchings as key themes in Week 7.

namedEntities.name: Bo Nix
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Second-year quarterback for the Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bo Nix led a historic comeback against the New York Giants, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, and ultimately securing a 33-32 win after a dramatic fourth-quarter surge.

namedEntities.name: Drake Maye
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback for the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage (91.3% vs. 88.5%) and became the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of passes, throw for over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in one game.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His 88.5% completion record set a franchise benchmark that Drake Maye recently broke, marking a significant milestone in the evolution of Patriots quarterback performance.

namedEntities.name: Tua Tagovailoa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tagovailoa had a disastrous performance with three interceptions, including one returned for a touchdown, leading to his benching in the fourth quarter of a 31-6 loss to the Cleveland Browns.

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Quarterback for the New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fields struggled in the first half, leading to his halftime benched, and was replaced by Tyrod Taylor, highlighting instability in the Jets' offensive leadership.

namedEntities.name: Jacoby Brissett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Backup quarterback for the Arizona Cardinals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brissett led the Cardinals in a game that ended in a 23-27 loss to the Green Bay Packers, with the team relying on him after a failed final drive.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Defensive player for the Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Parsons, acquired in a trade from the Dallas Cowboys, dominated the Cardinals’ final drive with a third sack, showcasing his impact as a defensive force.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vrabel, who was fired by the Jets in 2024, returned to win his first game against the Patriots, signaling a turnaround for the franchise.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Patriots are undergoing a transformation under Drake Maye, with the team achieving a strong win in Week 7 that marks a pivotal moment in rebuilding the franchise.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was defined by dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and high-profile quarterback benchings. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit against the New York Giants, becoming the first team since 2007 to reverse a 161-0 lead after three quarters. Second-year quarterback Bo Nix delivered a standout fourth-quarter performance, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, and sealing the win with a game-winning field goal. Meanwhile, New England Patriots' Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of his passes, throw for over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game. On the downside, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets suffered devastating losses, with Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields both benched due to poor performances. The Jets remain winless at 0-7, while the Dolphins' collapse highlighted growing instability. These events underscore a season marked by volatility, resilience, and major shifts in team dynamics and leadership.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
